title: Slides
text:
Using Bayesian Networks to Identify Significant Crime Events, Young Statisticians Workshop, 30 September 2020. Online.
Kriging vs Geographically Weighted Regression for Analysing Farm Experiments, Early Career and Student Statisticians Conference, 27 July 2021. Online.
Essential Statistical Concepts for Understanding the COVID-19 Pandemic, Perth Epidemiology Group, 30 March 2022. Online.
Identifying Black Holes and Neutron Stars in Large Astronomical Surveys using Gaussian Processes, HDR Milestone 1 presentation, Curtin University, 15 May 2023.
Identifying Astronomical Transients in Large Scale Surveys using Gaussian Processes, Australian Statistical Conference, University of Wollongong, 14 December 2023.
Beyond Light Curve Smoothing: Gaussian Processes as Vivid Descriptors of Variables and Transients, HDR Milestone 2 presentation, Curtin University, 10 June 2024.
Identifying transient astronomical sources in MeerKAT light curves using Gaussian processes, Australasian Applied Statistics Conference, Rottnest Island, 4 September 2024.
Gaussian process models for identifying variables and transients in large astronomical surveys, Astrophysics Group, Imperial College London, 16 September 2024.
Gaussian process regression for identifying variables and transients in ThunderKAT, ThunderKAT & X-KAT meeting, Politecnico di Milano Lecco Campus, 24 September 2024.
Playing in the Cosmic Backyard: A Statistician’s Journey into Astronomy, Early Career and Student Statisticians Conference, Curtin University, 19 November 2024. Online

“The best thing about being a statistician is that you get to play in everyone’s backyard.” – John Tukey

“We need to design aircraft or automotive displays to counteract visual illusions and we need to design statistical graphics to counteract probability illusions.” – Leland Wilkinson

title: Shih Ching Fu
text:
I’m a graduate student at the Curtin Institute of Radio Astronomy (CIRA). My research involves the application of Bayesian techniques to the analysis of astronomical time-series, namely light curves from radio, optical, and X-ray surveys.
My other activities include being Secretary of the WA Branch of the Statistical Society of Australia (SSA) and delivering R training as a certified Carpentries Instructor.
Contact me via the channels found at the bottom of this page.

“It is a capital mistake to theorize before one has data. Insensibly one begins to twist facts to suit theories, instead of theories to suit facts.” – Sherlock Holmes
